title: 108_s1451
content: The Act is titled the "Runaway, Homeless, and Missing Children Protection Act." It amends the findings section of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. The Congress recognizes the urgent need to provide temporary shelter and services for homeless youth, who are at risk of serious health and behavioral problems. It is the responsibility of the Federal Government to develop a national reporting system and effective care services for these vulnerable individuals. The Federal Government is responsible for developing a national reporting system and effective care services for homeless youth, including education, job skills, and employment opportunities. Improved coordination between Federal programs is necessary for a long-term strategy to address the needs of this population. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to change the heading to "Basic Center" and include testing for sexually transmitted diseases at the request of youth. Obsolete provisions related to certain allotments are repealed, and eligibility provisions are updated. SEC. 105 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to replace "juveniles" with "youth". SEC. 106 addresses state laws on capacity limitations for eligible centers. SEC. 107 pertains to maternity group homes. SEC. 107 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to include maternity group homes, providing pregnant or parenting youth with supportive living arrangements and parenting skills training. SEC. 108 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to extend shelter eligibility for youth under 18 until their 18th birthday or 180 days after the initial 540-day period. SEC. 109 updates coordination assurances for educational services, and SEC. 110 addresses coordination agreements. SEC. 110 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to coordinate services with McKinney-Vento school district liaisons for educational services. SEC. 111 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to develop a plan for proper referral of homeless youth to various services. SEC. 112 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to ensure coordination of programs and services for homeless youth by consulting with the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 113 clarifies grant authority for activities under this title. SEC. 114 makes a technical amendment by removing "temporary" from a section heading. SEC. 115 repeals an obsolete provision related to a study. SEC. 116 sets an age limit for homeless youth. SEC. 115 repeals an obsolete provision related to a study. SEC. 116 sets an age limit for homeless youth. SEC. 117 authorizes appropriations. SEC. 117 authorizes appropriations for the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act, specifying funding amounts for fiscal years 2004 to 2008 and adjusting the allocation percentages for different parts of the Act. SEC. 118 requires a report on strategies to end youth homelessness within 2 years. SEC. 119 mandates a study on housing services for youth exiting programs under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. SEC. 120 adds a restriction on the use of funds under the Act. SEC. 120 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act amends the Act to restrict the use of funds for distributing sterile needles for illegal drug injection. Any entity receiving funds must account for separate use of funds for such programs. The Congress acknowledges the grave danger faced by abducted children, the risks of physical harm and exploitation, and the challenges faced by parents and law enforcement in locating missing children. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children plays a crucial role in coordinating efforts across different levels of law enforcement. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children partners with various agencies to find missing children and prevent child victimization. It operates a national and worldwide network to transmit images and information about missing children to law enforcement globally. The Missing Children's Assistance Act is amended to authorize appropriations for the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children until 2008. This is part of a larger act reauthorizing programs for runaway and homeless youth.
